scenarios.description: Read a file inside the sandbox — should be allowed by sandbox freedom principle
scenarios.reasoning: The path is inside the designated sandbox directory. Sandbox freedom permits unrestricted reads and writes within /tmp/ironcurtain-sandbox.

scenarios.description: Write a new file inside the sandbox — should be allowed
scenarios.reasoning: Writing within the sandbox directory is explicitly permitted by the Sandbox freedom principle. No protected paths are involved.

scenarios.description: Read a sensitive system file outside the sandbox (/etc/passwd) — should be denied
scenarios.reasoning: The path is outside the sandbox. Least privilege principle denies access to resources not explicitly permitted. Reading /etc/passwd is not sanctioned by policy.

scenarios.description: Write a file outside the sandbox to a user's home directory — should escalate for human approval
scenarios.reasoning: Write operations outside the sandbox require explicit human approval per the Human oversight principle. This is not a deny because the operation may be legitimate but needs a human in the loop.

scenarios.description: Move a file from sandbox to another sandbox location — should be denied because move implies delete-path on source
scenarios.reasoning: All move operations are denied because the source argument carries a delete-path role, which constitutes a destructive operation violating the No destruction principle.

scenarios.description: Move a file from outside the sandbox to inside — should be denied
scenarios.reasoning: Move operations are unconditionally denied because source carries a delete-path role, which is a destructive operation regardless of source or destination paths.

scenarios.description: Path traversal attack attempting to escape sandbox via .. segments
scenarios.reasoning: After resolving the path traversal, the effective path is /etc/shadow which is outside the sandbox. The engine must canonicalize paths and deny access to anything outside /tmp/ironcurtain-sandbox.

scenarios.description: Create a nested directory inside the sandbox — should be allowed
scenarios.reasoning: Creating directories within the sandbox is covered by sandbox freedom. The write-path role on this path falls within /tmp/ironcurtain-sandbox.

scenarios.description: Create a directory outside the sandbox — should escalate
scenarios.reasoning: Creating a directory outside the sandbox is a write operation that requires explicit human approval per the Human oversight principle before the agent can proceed.

scenarios.description: Read multiple files all within the sandbox — should be allowed
scenarios.reasoning: All paths are within the sandbox directory. Sandbox freedom permits reading any files within /tmp/ironcurtain-sandbox.

scenarios.description: Read multiple files where one path is outside the sandbox — should be denied
scenarios.reasoning: Because one of the paths (/etc/hosts) is outside the sandbox, the least privilege principle requires denying the entire request. Mixed-scope batch reads are not permitted.

scenarios.description: Search files recursively inside the sandbox — should be allowed
scenarios.reasoning: The search root is within the sandbox directory. Read operations scoped entirely to /tmp/ironcurtain-sandbox are permitted by sandbox freedom.

scenarios.description: Search files with root outside the sandbox — should be denied
scenarios.reasoning: The search root /var/log is outside the sandbox. Least privilege denies read access to external filesystem paths not explicitly authorized by policy.

scenarios.description: Get file metadata for a file inside the sandbox — should be allowed
scenarios.reasoning: Retrieving metadata for a file within the sandbox is a read operation permitted by sandbox freedom. No destructive or external access is involved.

scenarios.description: Edit a file inside the sandbox using targeted line edits — should be allowed
scenarios.reasoning: edit_file targets a path inside the sandbox. Both the read-path and write-path roles for this path are within /tmp/ironcurtain-sandbox, so sandbox freedom applies.

scenarios.description: Edit a file outside the sandbox — should escalate for human approval
scenarios.reasoning: Editing a file outside the sandbox is a write operation requiring explicit human approval per the Human oversight principle. The path is not protected by structural invariants but is outside the permitted sandbox.

scenarios.description: Directory tree traversal rooted inside the sandbox — should be allowed
scenarios.reasoning: Generating a directory tree from within the sandbox is a read operation. It is fully contained within /tmp/ironcurtain-sandbox and is permitted by sandbox freedom.

scenarios.description: Read the audit log file directly — should be denied (protected path structural invariant)
scenarios.reasoning: The audit log /home/provos/src/ironcurtain/audit.jsonl is a protected path. Any write or delete is denied by structural invariant. Read access is also denied because the path is outside the sandbox and not explicitly permitted.

scenarios.description: Read a media file (image) inside the sandbox — should be allowed
scenarios.reasoning: Reading a media file within the sandbox is permitted by sandbox freedom. The path is fully inside /tmp/ironcurtain-sandbox and poses no risk.

scenarios.description: Path that starts with sandbox prefix but escapes via traversal — should be denied
scenarios.reasoning: Despite appearing to start within the sandbox prefix, path traversal resolves this to /root/.ssh/id_rsa which is well outside the sandbox. The engine canonicalizes paths before evaluation, so this is denied by the least privilege principle.
